key_points: House Judiciary Committee Chairman Jerry Nadler called for a DOJ review of Kyle Rittenhouse's acquittal.
Rittenhouse was acquitted after claiming self-defense in the shooting during Kenosha protests in 2020.
Federal charges against Rittenhouse are deemed unlikely due to the nature of his alleged crimes.
Federal law typically involves specific violations, none of which Rittenhouse is accused of.
The charges against Rittenhouse sparked debates over guns, vigilantism, and racial justice.
Rittenhouse, who was 17 at the time of the shootings, had claimed he was there to protect property.
Prosecutors portrayed Rittenhouse as a "wannabe soldier," but he testified in self-defense.
Judge Schroeder's handling of the trial, including dismissing a gun possession charge, drew attention.
The dismissal of the weapon charge was based on the length of the gun's barrel compared to state law.
The trial's outcome and judge's decisions have led to broader discussions on legal interpretations and self-defense laws.
spokespersons: Jerry Nadler (D-N.Y., House Judiciary Committee Chairman)
